div.head: Eliza Orme (1848–1937)
div.p: Eliza Orme was a granddaughter of the Reverend Edward Andrews (1786-1841), Ruskin's first tutor and a celebrated Congregationalist preacher when the Ruskins attended Dissenting chapel. Eliza's mother was Andrews's eldest daughter, also named Eliza (1816-92); and her sister was Emily who married Coventry Patmore. In Praeterita, Ruskin mentions the sisters together, in connection with his tutoring, starting at age ten, by Dr. Andrews: "Miss Andrews, the eldest sister of the 'Angel in the House' [Emily Patmore], was an extremely beautiful girl of seventeen; she sang 'Tambourgi, Tambourgi' with great spirit and a rich voice, went at blackberry time on rambles with us at the Norwood Spa, and made me feel generally that there was something in girls that I did not understand, and that was curiously agreeable". As noted by the editors of the Library Edition, Eliza, as Mrs. Orme, held a salon, which was frequented by the Pre-Raphaelites (Works, 35:73-74, 74 n. 1). John James Ruskin copied verses entitled “The Brave Hussar” by Eliza, in MS VI.

The younger Eliza Orme earned a LLB from the University of London and was a practicing lawyer, as well as a feminist and writer on women's issues. Her relevance to ERM lies in her sharing volumes of her grandfather's magazine, the Spiritual Times, with H. Robertson Nicoll, enabling him to track down Ruskin's first publications (see "On Skiddaw and Derwent Water": Nicollʼs Discovery of the Spiritual Times Ruskin Publications) Since Orme was unmarried and lived with her parents until their death (Howsam, “Orme, Eliza (1848–1937)”, perhaps Eliza became aware of copies of her grandfather's magazine when her mother died in 1892. Nicoll published his findings in 1895.
